text:
Pablo and his little sister, Deborah, are at a carnival. The carnival has several Ferris wheels for cildren of different ages. The two largest wheels, for older chidlren, take 60 seconds and 50 seconds to complete one revolution. The four smaller wheels tke 30, 20, 14, and 11 seconds to complete one revolution.

Pablo gets on at the bottom of a large Ferris wheel. Deborah gets on at the bottom of a small Ferris wheel. The rides begin at the same time.

For each ride,

  • How many seconds will pass before Pablo and Deborah are both at the bottom again?
  • How many times will each Ferris wheel have gone around?

The 60- and 20- Second Ferris Wheels

Pablo gets on the 60- second Ferris wheel, and Deborah gets on the 20-second Ferris wheel.

Small Ferris wheel: 20, 40, 60,...

Large Ferris wheel: 60, ...

Both Pablo and Deborah will be at the bottom again after 60 seconds, when Deborah has gone around three times and Pablo has gone around once. Students may not list multiples but just recognize that 60 is the first time they will both be at the bottom because 20 is a factor of 60.

The 50- and 30- second Ferris Wheels

Pablo gets on the 50-second Ferris wheel, and Deborah gets on the 30-second Ferris wheel.

Small Ferris wheel: 30, 60, 90, 120, 150, ...

Large Ferris wheel: 50, 100, 150, ...

Both Pablo and Deborah will be at the bottom again after 150 seconds, when Deborah has gone around five times and Pablo has gone around three times.

Again, students ma not list multiples like this but just use multiplication to guess and check, or some may just know that 30 × 5 = 150 and 50 × 3 = 150.

Some students may realize that 50 and 30 share a factor: (5 ⋅ 10) and (3 ⋅ 10). They may say that they "ignore the 10," find the multiples that 5 and 3 share, and then "re-multiple by 10." This is intuitively using the greatest common factor to help when finding the least common multiple.

150 is the 5th multiple of 30, so the small Ferris wheel will have gone around 5 times.

30 seconds ⋅ 5 = 150 seconds

150 is the 3rd multiple of 50, so the small Ferris wheel will have gone around 3 times.

50 seconds ⋅ 3 = 150 seconds

The 14- and 11- Second Ferris Wheels

For fun, Pablo gets on the ride for young people that takes 14 seconds to complete a revolution, and Deborah gets on the ride that takes 11 seconds.

Small Ferris wheel: 11, 22, 33, 44, 55, 66, 77, 88, 99, 110. 121. 132. 143. 154, ...

Large Ferris wheel: 14, 28, 42, 56, 70, 84, 98, 112, 126, 140, 154, ...

Both Pablo and Deborah will be at the bottom again after154 seconds, when Deborah has gone around 11 times and Jeremy has gone around 14 times.

This may be the first situation in which students try a different strategy for keeping track of when the multiples will match. Because the numbers (14 and 11) are realtively prime, the only common factor that they share is 1. This might generate new strategies for students.
